APPLICATION CHNJC 64727 S1872-2067(25)64727-9 10.1016/S1872-2067(25)64727-9 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of formation mechanism for NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs and NiCo2S4@CoS2 DSHSs. Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns of CoNi-G SSs (A) and CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs (B). (b) XRD patterns of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs (A), NiCo2S4@CoS2 DSHSs (B), and NiCo2S4 YSSs (C). Fig. 3 SEM (a–c) and TEM (d–f) images of CoNi-G SSs (a,d), CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs (b,e), and NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS x -2/1 DSHSs (c,f). Fig. 4 (a–c) SEM images of S-NiCoMo-2. (d,e) TEM images of S-NiCoMo-2. (f) HRTEM image of S-NiCoMo-2. (g) elemental mapping images of S-NiCoMo-2. Fig. 5 (a) The XPS patterns of S-NiCoMo-2. High-resolution XPS spectra of Co 2p (b), Ni 2p (c); Mo 3d (d), and S 2p (e) of S-NiCoMo-2. (f) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm measurements. Fig. 6 Polarization curves (a), histograms of overpotentials at different current densities (b), and corresponding Tafel slopes (c) of S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, S-NiCoMo-0, and NiCo2S4 YSSs towards HER. Polarization curves (d), histograms of overpotentials at different current densities (e) and corresponding Tafel slopes (f) of S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, S-NiCoMo-0, and NiCo2S4 YSSs towards OER. (g, h) C dl values of S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, S-NiCoMo-0, and NiCo2S4 YSSs towards HER and OER were obtained from current density versus scan rates. (i) Nyquist plots and equivalent circuit for S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, S-NiCoMo-0, and NiCo2S4 YSSs. Fig. 7 (a) OER polarization curves of S-NiCoMo-4 and S-NiCoMo-2 in 1 mol L–1 KOH and 1 mol L–1 TMAOH, respectively. In situ Raman spectra of S-NiCoMo-4 (b) and S-CoMo-4 (c) during the applied potential range from OCP to 1.7 V vs. RHE. (d, e) show the DEMS measurements of the 32O2, 34O2, and 36O2 signals from the reaction products of 18O-labeled S-NiCoMo-4 and S-CoMo-4, respectively. (f) in situ Raman spectroscopy of HER on S-NiCoMo-4 at different potentials immediately after OER tests. (g) mechanism diagram of synergistic catalysis under AEM and LOM pathways. Fig. 8 (a) Chronopotentiometry curves recorded at 10 mA cm–2 of S-NiCoMo-2 towards HER and S-NiCoMo-4 towards OER in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH solution. (b) Polarization curves at 10 mA cm–2 of S-NiCoMo-4||S-NiCoMo-2 and Pt/C||RuO2 couples towards overall water electrolysis. (c) Experimental and theoretical values of gas production for S-NiCoMo-4||S-NiCoMo-2. Electrolyte 1 mol L–1 KOH. (d) a drainage device fabricated using an H-type electrolytic cell. (e) Chronopotentiometry curves at 10 mA cm–2 of S-NiCoMo-2||S-NiCoMo-4 and Pt/C||RuO2 couples towards overall water electrolysis. (f) Comparison of the water electrolysis voltage obtained at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 from previous research and that achieved using our NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs catalyst in an alkaline medium. Optical image of the AEM water splitting device (g) and schematic diagram (h). (i) Stability testing of the S-NiCoMo-4|| S-NiCoMo-2 electrode pairs in EWS using the AEM water splitting device (constant current charging, current density = 0.5 A cm–2) in 1 mol L–1 KOH. Fig. 9 (a) DFT calculated PDOS of isolated (002) MoS2 nanoparticles, (112) CoS2 surface and CoS2/MoS2 heterointerface. (b) Charge density difference at the CoS2/MoS2 heterointerface. (c) Band diagrams of semiconductor MoS2 and metallic CoS2 before and after the formation of Mott-Schottky interactions. Available online 20 July 2025 Article Dual-shell hollow nanospheres NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2: Enhancing catalytic activity for oxygen evolution reaction and achieving water splitting via the unique synergistic effects of mechanisms of adsorption-desorption and lattice oxygen oxidation Yang Chen a Yu Tang b Leiyun Han a Jiayan Liu a Yingjie Hua c Xudong Zhao a Xiaoyang Liu a c * a State Key Laboratory of Inorganic Synthesis and Preparative Chemistry, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China State Key Laboratory of Inorganic Synthesis and Preparative Chemistry College of Chemistry Jilin University Changchun Jilin 130012 China State Key Laboratory of Inorganic Synthesis and Preparative Chemistry, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China b Key Laboratory of Physics and Technology for Advanced Batteries (Ministry of Education), College of Physics, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China Key Laboratory of Physics and Technology for Advanced Batteries (Ministry of Education) College of Physics Jilin University Changchun Jilin 130012 China Key Laboratory of Physics and Technology for Advanced Batteries (Ministry of Education), College of Physics, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China c Key Laboratory of Electrochemical Energy Storage and Energy Conversion of Hainan Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hainan Normal University, Haikou 571158, Hainan, China Key Laboratory of Electrochemical Energy Storage and Energy Conversion of Hainan Province School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hainan Normal University Haikou Hainan 571158 China Key Laboratory of Electrochemical Energy Storage and Energy Conversion of Hainan Province, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hainan Normal University, Haikou 571158, Hainan, China * Corresponding author Activating both metal and lattice oxygen sites for efficient oxygen evolution reactions (OER) is a critical challenge. This study pioneers a novel approach, employing cobalt-nickel glycerate solid spheres (CoNi-G SSs) as self-sacrificial templates to synthesize yolk-shell structured CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 nanospheres. The derived NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 double-shelled hollow nanospheres integrate the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) and lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM), enabling synergistic dual catalytic pathways. Nickel modulation facilitates active species reconstruction in NiCo2S4, enhancing lattice oxygen activity and optimizing the LOM pathway. Characterization results indicate that anode activation triggered the redox processes of metal and lattice oxygen sites, involving the formation and re-filling of oxygen vacancies. Additionally, the CoS2/MoS2 heterostructure enhances the AEM pathway, as supported by density functional theory calculations, which demonstrate optimized adsorption of intermediates for both hydrogen evolution reaction and OER. The assembled anion exchange membrane water splitting device can deliver a catalytic current of 500 mA cm–2 at 1.74 V under commercial catalytic operating conditions (1 mol L–1 KOH) for 150 h, with negligible degradation. This work provides important insights into the understanding of OER mechanisms and the design of high-performance water-splitting electrocatalysts, while also opening new avenues for developing multifunctional materials with multi-shell structures. Graphical Abstract A novel dual-shell hollow nanospheres catalyst (NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2) integrates adsorbate evolution mechanism and lattice oxygen mechanism, balancing catalytic activity and stability for efficient oxygen evolution reaction and water splitting. Keywords Adsorbate evolution mechanism Lattice oxygen mechanism Water-splitting ZIF-67 NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 Dual-shell hollow nanospheres 1 Introduction As environmental and energy problems become increasingly critical, new methods to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels have attracted widespread attention [ 1 ]. Clean and renewable energy sources are promising alternatives to carbon-based fuels [ 2–4 ]. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a crucial half-reaction in advanced energy systems such as water splitting, fuel cells, and CO2 reduction [ 5–8 ]. Additionally, slow kinetics and the high energy barrier of the rigid O–O bond hinder the progress of these technologies [ 9 ]. There are two main OER mechanisms, namely adsorbate evolution (AEM) and the lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) [ 10,11 ]. In the AEM, metal sites act as redox centers, involving oxygen intermediates and limiting the minimum overpotential to 0.37 V [ 12,13 ]. In the LOM, lattice oxygen participates in O2 formation, breaking the scaling relationship limitations of the AEM and offering more favorable thermodynamics [ 14 ]. However, lattice oxygen involvement can lead to structural disorder and performance decline [ 15,16 ]. Undoubtedly, constructing a mechanism that combines AEM and LOM could balance catalytic activity and stability [ 15,17,18 ]. Developing coupled catalytic systems that activate both metal and lattice oxygen redox pairs remains a significant challenge [ 19 ]. Noble metal oxides, such as RuO2 and IrO2, are benchmarks for OER electrocatalysts, but their high cost, low abundance, and limited durability hinder large-scale application [ 20 ]. Transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) are ideal alternatives with metallic properties, tunable composition, and structural flexibility [ 21 ]. In practice, transition metal oxyhydroxides (MOOH, M = Co, Ni, or Fe), formed through irreversible structural changes during OER electro-oxidation, are the actual active species. Among them, NiCo-based oxyhydroxides are replacing RuO2 and IrO2 as OER catalysts [ 22–24 ]. Recent findings suggest high-valence metal centers in OER-reconstructed oxyhydroxides can trigger the LOM pathway, enhancing OER activity [ 25,26 ]. This provides important insights for designing catalysts with synergistic OER pathways through electrocatalytic reconstruction strategies. Metal-organic framework compounds (MOFs) are crystalline microporous materials with large specific surface areas, unique porosity, and customizable functions [ 27 ]. Recently, MOFs have been demonstrated to be ideal precursors for functional transition metal (TM)-carbon-based nanohybrids used in low-cost and efficient water electrolysis electrocatalysts [ 28,29 ]. Coupling the CoS2 with materials such as semiconductive MoS2 to form heterostructures has proven effective [ 30 ]. Moreover, the semiconductor characteristics of MoS2 and the metallic properties of CoS2 allow for a Mott-Schottky interaction, where electrons flow across the heterointerface, regulating charge distribution and tuning intermediate species adsorption [ 31,32 ]. Therefore, electrocatalysts with multiple elemental components are expected to exhibit higher catalytic efficiency and greater potential for OER and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) applications. Imparting controllable morphological nanostructures to OER catalysts enhances key parameters such as exposed active sites and mass transport, improving catalytic performance [ 33–36 ]. Porous micro/nanostructures with hollow features increase active surface exposure and boost mass diffusion, significantly enhancing electrocatalytic performance [ 37 ]. Additionally, the cavities in the hollow structure expose more active sites and act as ion “reservoirs”, shortening transport distance and optimizing mass transfer [ 38 ]. The double-shell hollow structure further amplifies these benefits, improving catalytic performance. However, research on ternary transition metal sulfide bifunctional catalysts with a three-dimensional double-shell structure derived from MOFs is limited due to challenges in controlling the composition and morphology of MOFs. Regulating ternary metal sulfide catalysts’ composition and shell structure to improve electrocatalytic activity and stability remains a significant challenge. This study combines a MOF-derived core-shell structure with multi-element components to create a double-shelled hollow spheres (DSHSs) catalyst that integrates both LOM and AEM mechanisms. Using a MOF-derived core-shell nanohybrid as a precursor, and a NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs catalyst was synthesized through rational design. The core-shell structure enhances both activity and stability, while the dual-shell synergy optimizes reaction pathways, significantly boosting catalytic performance. NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs serve as sacrificial templates for high-valence MOOH, with Ni and Mo acting as modulators through self-sacrificial templating and chemical etching. Ni promotes the complete reconstruction of active species in NiCo2S4, enhancing lattice oxygen activity and increasing the LOM pathway for the OER. Characterization confirms that anode activation triggers redox processes at metal and lattice oxygen sites, forming and re-filling oxygen vacancies. In-situ Raman spectroscopy and 18O isotope-labeled differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) confirm an OER mechanism compatible with both AEM and LOM pathways. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra confirm the presence of the CoS2/MoS2 heterostructure, with Mo species modulation optimizing the AEM pathway. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations show that CoS2/MoS2 active sites optimize the adsorption of HER and OER intermediates. The Mott-Schottky interaction between semiconductor MoS2 and metallic CoS2 modulates the electronic structure, thereby improving water-splitting performance. Under Ni and Mo modulation, the NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 system achieves synergistic catalysis through both AEM and LOM pathways, enhancing OER catalytic activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis 2.1.1 Synthesis of CoNi-G SSs Synthesis of CoNi-glycerate solid spheres (CoNi-G SSs). The synthesis was carried out according to Lou's previously reported method with slight modification [ 39,40 ]. Specifically, 0.275 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.1 mmol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved into a mixture solution of isopropanol (40 mL) and glycerol (8 mL). After stirring for 30 min at 800 rpm, the as-prepared solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 mL) and kept at 180 °C for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the brown precipitates were separated using centrifugation, washed three times with ethanol, and dried at 60 °C. Additionally, the preparation of Co-G SSs follows the same method as described above, except that 0.1 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O is replaced with 0.1 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O. 2.1.2 Synthesis of (NH4)2MoS4 In a typical process, 15 g of (NH4)6Mo7O2·4H2O was uniformly distributed in 10 mL of ammonia hydroxide to form the homogeneous suspension under stirring, and then 120 g of (NH4)2S solution (20% in water) was added. The obtained mixed solution was heated at 60 °C for 2 h. Finally, the (NH4)2MoS4 precipitate was obtained by centrifugation after an ice bath [ 41 ]. 2.1.3 Synthesis of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs and Co-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs CoNi glycolic acid solid spheres (CoNi-G SSs) were prepared using an improved method as previously reported; experimental details can be found in the supporting information. First, 100 mg of CoNi-G SSs were uniformly dispersed in 5 mL of water, resulting in a light pink solution. Next, 5 mL of an aqueous solution containing 200 mg of 2-methylimidazole (2-MI) was added to the above solution, followed by an aging reaction for 15 h at room temperature to yield a purple product, labeled as CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs. The product was collected by centrifugation and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 6 h. Lastly, the product was collected by centrifugation and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 6 h. Additionally, the synthesis method for Co-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs is the same as described above, except that CoNi-G SSs is replaced with Co-G SSs. 2.1.4 Synthesis of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoSx YSSs and Co-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoSx YSSs YSSs The 60 mg of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs obtained from Section 2.1 was evenly dispersed in 30 mL of anhydrous ethanol to obtain a purple suspension, and 5 mL of an aqueous solution containing 30 mg of (NH4)2MoS4 was added to the above purple suspension and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The initial mass ratio of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs to (NH4)2MoS4 was 2:1. The purple-black reaction precipitate was then collected by centrifugation, washed three times with water and anhydrous ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 6 h. This product was labeled as CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoS x -2/1 YSSs. The synthesis process of the product CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoS x -4/1 YSSs is similar to that of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoSx-2/1YSSs mentioned above, except with an initial mass ratio of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSS to (NH4)2MoS4 of 4:1. Additionally, the synthesis method for Co-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoS x -4/1 YSSs is the same as described above, except that CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs is replaced with Co-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs. 2.1.5 Synthesis of S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4 and S-CoMo-4 In a typical synthesis procedure, 30 mg of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoS x -2/1 YSSs were dispersed in 25 mL of anhydrous ethanol. Subsequently, 30 mg of thioacetamide (TAA) was added, and the mixture was stirred at 500 rpm for 12 h. The resulting mixture was then transferred to a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave lined with polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) and maintained at 120 °C for 4 h in the oven. After naturally cooling to room temperature, the black precipitate was separated by centrifugation and washed three times with anhydrous ethanol. The product was then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 6 h. In order to improve the crystallinity of the synthesized product, it was placed in a tube furnace and heated to 500 °C at a heating rate of 2 °C min–1 under nitrogen protection for 2 h and naturally cooled to room temperature. The product obtained through the above process was recorded as NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2-2/1 DSHSs, and designated as S-NiCoMo-2. Additionally, the synthesis process of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@ Co-MoS x -4/1YSSs was same as the above process, except that the mass ratio of the reaction starting material CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs to (NH4)2MoS4 was 4:1, and designated as S-NiCoMo-4. Additionally, the synthesis method for Co3S4@CoS2/MoS2-4/1 DSHSs is the same as described above, except that CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoS x -4/1YSSs is replaced with Co-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoS x -4/1 YSSs, and designated as S-CoMo-4. 2.1.6 Synthesis of S-NiCoMo-0 and NiCo2S4 YSSs The 30 mg of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs were dispersed in 25 mL of anhydrous ethanol, followed by the addition of 30 mg of TAA. After stirring at 500 rpm for 12 h, the mixture was transferred to a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave lined with PTFE and maintained at 120 °C for 4 h in the oven. After naturally cooling to room temperature, the black precipitate was obtained through centrifugation. The precipitate underwent three rounds of washing with anhydrous ethanol and was then subjected to drying in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for a duration of 6 h. To enhance crystallinity of the synthesized product, the synthesized product was placed in a tube furnace under a nitrogen atmosphere and heated to 500 °C at a rate of 2 °C min–1. After 2 h, it was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The resulting product was named NiCo2S4@CoS2 DSHSs and abbreviated as S-NiCoMo-0. In the synthesis process of NiCo2S4 YSSs, with the exception that CoNi-G SSs YSSs was used instead of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs, other procedures were the same as the synthesis method of S-NiCoMo-0 mentioned above. 2.2 Characterizations and electrochemical measurements The surface morphologies of all as-obtained catalysts were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-5600LV, Japan). Moreover, the further internal structures of these samples were investigated via high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, TECNAI G2 ST win F20, FEI). X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/MAX2550, Cu Kα , λ = 0.15418 nm, Japan) was utilized to measure the crystal structures with the range of 10°–80° at a rate of 10° min–1. The elemental composition of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs was tested through an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (ESCALAB 250 (Mg Kα , USA)). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured and analyzed through Micromeritics ASAP-2040. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements All the electrochemical tests were performed at ambient environment by the electrochemical workstation (CHI 660E; Shanghai Chenhua Instruments, China). The graphite rod, Hg/HgO electrode, and carbon fiber paper (CFP, 1 cm×1.5 cm) modified with samples were used as the counter electrode, reference electrode, and working electrode, respectively. The working electrode was prepared as follows: 10 mg of catalysts was firstly dispersed in a mixed solution of water (480 µL), ethanol (480 µL) and 5 wt% Dupont Nafion 117 solution (40 µL), followed by 30 min sonication to form a homogeneous suspension. 80 µL of suspension was pipetted onto a piece of clean CFP with a controlled coating area of 1 cm2 and then dried at 60 °C in a vacuum oven for measurements. The measured potentials were calibrated to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to the Nernst equation: E (V vs. RHE) = E (V vs. Hg/HgO) + 0.098 + 0.0592 × pH. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were performed at a scan rate of 5 mV s–1. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of the catalysts was evaluated by comparing the double-layer capacitance (C dl) under a potential window without redox reactions. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out at the open circuit potential with a frequency range from 10–2 Hz to 105 Hz with an amplitude of 5 mV. All LSV curves were corrected with the iR-compensation method. The ohmic drop correction was performed by a positive feedback method with a compensation level of 90%. The hydrogen/oxygen evolution reaction (HER/OER) and water splitting were tested in a 1.0 mol L–1 KOH solution (pH = 14, 300 mL) using the three- and two electrode systems, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Composition and morphology As shown in Fig. 1 , we conducted a detailed study on the formation mechanism of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs, which is discussed in detail in the Supporting Information (SI) under the section “Formation Mechanism of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs Catalysts”. The XRD pattern of CoNi-glycerate solid spheres (CoNi-G SSs) is depicted in curve A of Fig. 2(a) , featuring a broad characteristic diffraction peak at an approximate diffraction angle of 10.6°, which corresponds to the distinctive diffraction peak of CoNi-G SSs [ 40 ]. Curve B of Fig. 2(a) shows the XRD pattern of the synthesized product, CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 yolk shell structured nanospheres (CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs). The synthesis process of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs was described in SI. The boxed area in the figure highlights a broad diffraction peak of CoNi-G SSs, which corresponds to a 2θ diffraction angle of approximately 10.6°. Additionally, the Pentagram symbols, at 2θ diffraction angles of 7.3, 10.3, 12.6, 17.8, 24.2, and 26.4°correspond to the characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to the crystal planes (100), (110), (111), (211), (311), and (320) of zeolite 4A (Co) (ZIF-67, ICDD, No.43-0144). This confirms the successful synthesis of ZIF-67 and demonstrates that the sample CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs comprised CoNi-G SSs and ZIF-67 [ 42 ]. Fig. S1 illustrates the XRD pattern of the synthesized (NH4)2MoS4, with its characteristic diffraction peaks matching the standard diffraction peaks of (NH4)2MoS4 (ICDD, No.048-1662) [ 43,44 ]. Additionally, we conducted an XRD characterization of the sample S-NiCoMo-2, and the test results were presented in Fig. 2(b). Specifically, curves A, B, and C represent the XRD patterns of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2-2/1 DSHSs (Abbreviated as S-NiCoMo-2), NiCo2S4@CoS2 DSHSs (Abbreviated as S-NiCoMo-0), and NiCo2S4, respectively. Taking S-NiCoMo-2 as an example, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 32.2°, 36.2°, 39.7°, 46.3°, and 54.9° correspond to the (200), (210), (211), (220), and (311) crystal planes of cubic-structured CoS2 (ICDD, No.41-1471) [ 45,46 ]. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 14.4° and 39.7° correspond to the (002) and (103) crystal planes of hexagonal MoS2 (ICDD, No.037-1492) [ 47,48 ]. The diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 16.3°, 26.9°, 31.3°, 38.1°, 47.4°, 50.5°, and 55.3° correspond to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440) crystal planes of cubic-structured NiCo2S4 (ICDD No.20-0782) [ 49,50 ]. This confirms that the synthesized material, S-NiCoMo-2, is a NiCo2S4, CoS2, and MoS2 composite. The synthesized NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2-4/1 DSHSs (Abbreviated as S-NiCoMo-4) share the same composition as S-NiCoMo-2, both being composites of NiCo2S4, CoS2, and MoS2. Additionally, XRD analysis was performed on the S-NiCoMo-0 and NiCo2S4 YSSs, and the results were presented in Fig. 2(b). Based on the above discussion results, we can infer that S-NiCoMo-0 is composed of NiCo2S4 and CoS2, and NiCo2S4 YSSs are composed of NiCo2S4. SEM and TEM images of CoNi-G SSs were presented in Figs. 3(a) and (d) , and Figs. S2(a) and (b), respectively. As can be seen from the figures, the synthesized CoNi-G SSs were solid nanospheres with a smooth surface and an average diameter of approximately 490 nm. Fig. S3(a) shows the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) pattern of CoNi-G SSs, showing that the atomic ratio of Co to Ni in CoNi-G SSs is 2.75:1. The EDS pattern corresponding to the sample CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs is shown in Fig. S3(b). It shows that the atomic percentage of N atoms was 73.7%, of which the N atoms provided by 2-MI and ZIF-67, which were obtained by the coordination reaction between Co2+ and 2-MI. According to the above results, it can be inferred that at room temperature and when water is used as the solvent, Co2+ in CoNi-G SSs continuously diffused into the solution and reacted with 2-MI to generate the outer shell of ZIF-67 and gradually coated the surface of CoNi-G SSs. As the reaction proceeded, it can be observed from Fig. S2(a) and Fig. 3(e) that the average diameter of the self-sacrificial template CoNi-G SSs decreased from its original 490 nm to approximately 360 nm. This further confirmed that the formation of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs occurred through a self-assembly reaction initiated by the self-sacrificial template CoNi-G SSs and 2-MI. The SEM and TEM images of CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs were shown in Figs. 3(b) and (e), revealing core-shell nanospheres with a rough and porous surface. During the synthesis of S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4, the introduction of different proportions of (NH4)2MoS4 into the CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 YSSs solution yielded CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@ Co-MoS x -2/1 YSSs and CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoS x -4/1 YSSs products with a Mo atomic ratio of approximately 2:1. Their EDS patterns were shown in Figs. S3(c) and (d), respectively. Under hydrothermal sulfidation conditions, CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67@Co-MoS x -2/1 YSSs reacted with TAA solution via a chemical etching/anion exchange process to yield NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS x -2/1 DSHSs. SEM and TEM images are shown in Figs. 3(c) and (f), respectively. The images show that NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS x -2/1 DSHSs exhibited a morphology of rough nanospheres with an average diameter of 570 nm, with distinct gaps between the inner and outer shell layers. Furthermore, following the hydrothermal sulfidation process, a small portion of unsulfidized core structures persisted within the core of CoNi-G SSs but were subsequently eliminated during the carbonization process. After hydrothermal sulfidation, the inner shell of CoNi-G SSs transformed into hollow NiCo2S4. The desired product, S-NiCoMo-2, was obtained following carbonization with a hollow double-shell structure. Taking S-NiCoMo-2 as an example, SEM images of the samples subjected to carbonization treatment of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS x -2/1 DSHSs were presented in Fig. 4(a) , showing the resulting S-NiCoMo-2 with a surface featuring rough, uneven nanospheres. Based on the particle size statistics in Fig. S4, it can be inferred that the average diameter of S-NiCoMo-2 nanospheres was approximately 560 to 570 nm. SEM test results of different regions of sonically fractured S-NiCoMo-2 are shown in Figs. 4(b) and (c). These images reveal that the cross-sections of S-NiCoMo-2 consist of two hollow hemispheres, representing a distinct double-shell structure. Furthermore, as shown in Figs. 4(d) and (e), TEM analysis further revealed the internal structure of S-NiCoMo-2. The images showed that S-NiCoMo-2 exhibited distinct shell boundaries and double-shell structural features, with the double-shell structure well preserved. In Fig. 4(e), the inner hollow sphere of S-NiCoMo-2 had a diameter of approximately 420 nm, with a gap of about 30 nm from the outer shell, while the outer shell had a thickness of around 30 nm. Fig. 4(f) shows the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) of S-NiCoMo-2. In Fig. 4(f), interplanar spacings of 0.244, 0.271, and 0.398 nm were observed, corresponding to the (006) crystal plane of MoS2, the (221) crystal plane of CoS2, and the (642) crystal plane of NiCo2S4, respectively. The HR-TEM images also reveal a distinct heterojunction interface between MoS2 and CoS2, as highlighted by the yellow lines; this interface is a characteristic of heterostructures and is expected to facilitate intermediates’ adsorption and/or desorption [ 32,51 ]. Furthermore, the distribution of different elements in S-NiCoMo-2 was investigated, and the corresponding elemental mapping in Fig. 4(g) demonstrated the uniform distribution of Co, Ni, Mo, and S elements in S-NiCoMo-2. Fig. 5(a) demonstrates the analysis of the chemical states of the prepared materials using XPS. The XPS patterns of the material were presented in Fig. 5(a), providing additional confirmation of the presence of Co, Mo, Ni, and S elements. For S-NiCoMo-2, the fitted XPS pattern of Co 2p in Fig. 5(b) shows that the two main peaks at electron binding energies of 778.8 and 794.1 eV, respectively, correspond to the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 energy levels of Co3+. The two main peaks at electron binding energies of 781.5 and 798.6 eV correspond to the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 energy levels of Co2+, respectively, accompanied by two broad satellite peaks [ 52 ]. As shown in Fig. S10, the high-resolution XPS spectra of S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, and S-NiCoMo-0 are presented. Compared to S-NiCoMo-0, the Co 2p XPS spectra of S-NiCoMo-4 and S-NiCoMo-2 show varying degrees of blue shifts in the Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2 peaks, with a larger blue shift observed as the MoS2 content increases, as shown in Fig. S11(a). This indicates strong Mott-Schottky contact at the heterointerface between CoS2 and MoS2. To further understand the electron transfer properties within the Mott-Schottky heterojunction, we determined the work functions of CoS2 and MoS2 by ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) analysis (calculation details can be found in the SI). According to the UPS spectra shown in Figs. S9 (a)–(d), the binding energies of the second cutoff edges for CoS2 and MoS2 are 16.545 and 16.265 eV, respectively. Using Equation S10, the work functions of CoS2 and MoS2 are calculated to be 4.655 and 4.935 eV, respectively. When a Mott-Schottky heterojunction is formed between CoS2 and MoS2, electrons migrate from the material with the lower work function (CoS2) to the one with the higher work function (MoS2). This electron migration leads to a redistribution of electron density between the two materials, altering the electronic environment on both sides of CoS2 and MoS2. This electron density redistribution facilitates intermediates’ adsorption and desorption, significantly enhancing the reaction kinetics of both HER and OER. Similarly, the fitted XPS pattern of Ni 2p was shown in Fig. 5(c), with two main peaks at electron binding energies of 852.3 and 869.8 eV corresponding to the Ni2+ 2p 3/2 and Ni2+ 2p 1/2 energy levels, respectively, and two main peaks at electron binding energies of 856.7 and 874.4 eV corresponding to the Ni3+ 2p 3/2 and Ni3+ 2p 1/2 energy levels, accompanied by two broad satellite peaks [ 53,54 ]. In Fig. 5(d), the two peaks at electron binding energies of 229.1 and 232.3 eV correspond to the Mo 3d 5/2 and Mo 3d 3/2 energy levels of the semiconducting MoS2. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. S11(b), compared to the binding energy of standard MoS2, there is a red shift in the characteristic peak of MoS2, indicating a strong Mott-Schottky interaction between CoS2 and MoS2. The peak at 235.4 eV for elemental Mo matches the 3d 3/2 energy level of Mo6+ [ 55 ]. In the XPS pattern of S 2p shown in Fig. 5(e), two peaks correspond to the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 energy levels of S. The electron binding energies of 161.2 and 162.3 eV were indicative of S2– in sulfide, and the peak at 163.5 eV suggested the presence of sulfur in a thiolate-type environment. The peak at 168.1 eV was attributed to surface oxidation in the air [ 55 ]. As shown in Fig. 5(f), we further conducted N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm measurements to assess the specific surface areas and porosity of S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, and S-NiCoMo-0. Because a hysteresis loop was observed in the range of P/P 0 = 0.4–1, the test results exhibited the characteristics of type-IV isotherms [ 56 ]. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas of S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, S-CoMo-4, S-NiCoMo-0, and NiCo2S4 YSSs were 47, 45, 43.76, 37.62 and 40 m2 g–1, respectively. The BET data of S-CoMo-4 and NiCo2S4 YSSs are shown in Fig. S12. These measurements reflect the larger internal spaces and thinner outer shell layers of S-NiCoMo-2 and NiCoMo-4, increasing specific surface areas. Consequently, a larger electrode/electrolyte interface was provided for electrochemical reactions. From the above results, it can be deduced that S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 exhibit higher specific surface areas and pore sizes, which were conducive to significantly increasing the number of electrochemical active sites and the adsorption capacity of electrolytes. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs for water electrolysis At room temperature, using a three-electrode system, the electrocatalytic performance of S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 for water electrolysis was first assessed in an alkaline medium (1.0 mol L–1 KOH, pH = 14). As shown in Figs. 6(a) and (b) , the electrocatalytic HER performance of S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4 and Pt/C was evaluated through LSV in a 1.0 mol L–1 KOH solution saturated with N2 and compared with the corresponding test results of S-NiCoMo-0 and NiCo2S4 YSSs. At the current density of 10 mA cm–2 (η 10), S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4 and Pt/C showed overpotentials of 87, 148 and 27 mV, respectively, whereas S-NiCoMo-0 and NiCo2S4 YSSs exhibited overpotentials of 263 and 169 mV, respectively. This indicates that S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 demonstrated superior electrocatalytic performance at the current density of η 10. Fig. 6(c) displays Tafel plots of LSV curves for S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, S-NiCoMo-0, and NiCo2S4 YSSs samples based on HER, illustrating the inherent characteristics of these electrocatalysts in HER. As one of the key kinetic parameters, the calculation formula for the Tafel slope was given by Eq. (1), where “b“ represents the Tafel slope. (1) η = blog j + a The Tafel slopes obtained from the LSV curves for S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4 and Pt/C electrode materials were 52, 73 and 33 mV dec–1 respectively, significantly lower than the Tafel slopes of NiCo2S4 YSSs (95 mV dec–1) and S-NiCoMo-0 (132 mV dec–1). The Tafel slope decreased from 132 mV dec–1 for S-NiCoMo-0 to 52 mV dec–1 for S-NiCoMo-2, with a reduced overpotential at the same current density. This provides compelling evidence of the catalytic activity and kinetic enhancement in alkaline HER resulting from the incorporation of Mo elements. This improvement was likely attributed to the electron-modulating effect of Mo sites, which promotes the dissociation of water [ 57 ]. Moreover, in Figs. 6(d) and (e), the electrocatalytic OER performance of S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 was assessed in a N2-saturated 1.0 mol L–1 KOH solution using LSV, and the results were compared with those of S-NiCoMo-0 and NiCo2S4 YSSs. At a current density of η 10, S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 exhibited overpotentials of 294 and 232 mV, respectively, while S-NiCoMo-0, RuO2 and NiCo2S4 YSSs displayed overpotentials of 336, 324 and 311 mV, respectively. It can be seen that the electrocatalytic OER performance of S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 has been significantly improved. Fig. 6(f) displays the Tafel slopes of LSV curves for S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-4, S-NiCoMo-0, and NiCo2S4 YSSs based on OER, still using Eq. (1). S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 exhibited Tafel slopes of 97 and 81 mV dec–1, respectively, which were notably lower than that of RuO2(103 mV dec–1), S-NiCoMo-0 (124 mV dec–1) and NiCo2S4 YSSs (117 mV dec–1). These results indicate that after Mo element doping, the OER catalytic activity and kinetics of S-NiCoMo-4 have been greatly improved, demonstrating the positive impact of Mo doping on OER. The Tafel slopes are consistent with the HER and OER performances, where S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 exhibit the smallest Tafel slopes of 52 and 81 mV dec–1, respectively, during HER and OER processes, which are much lower than those of S-NiCoMo-0. Moreover, since the Tafel slope value falls within the range of (40–120) mV dec–1, the HER activity on the heterostructure of S-NiCoMo-2 is controlled by the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism (H2O + e– → H* + OH– (Volmer), H* + H2O → H2 + OH– (Heyrovsky)) [ 58 ]. Therefore, this indicates that the reaction kinetics of HER and OER are most favorable under the action of S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4. In other words, this suggests that the construction of the Mott-Schottky heterojunction between CoS2 and MoS2 can significantly accelerate mass/charge transfer and promote intermediate adsorption/desorption, which is highly beneficial for HER and OER performances. It is generally believed that the primary electrochemical active sites of MoS2-based electrocatalysts are on the metal edge surface containing sulfur vacancies, while the base surface usually contains fully coordinated sulfur atoms that are functionally chemically inert. In the outer shell of S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4, the Mo-S edges of MoS2 contribute numerous active edge sites, and the presence of Co reduces the free energy of hydrogen adsorption at the S edge of MoS2. Moreover, the incorporation of Co elements at the S edges of MoS2 in S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 enhances catalysis, making the less active S edges more active [ 59 ]. NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs were designed as composite materials composed of Co, Mo, Ni, and S elements, exhibiting a significant element synergistic effect. The less active S edges became more active in the presence of Co, resulting in increased electrochemical active sites. In our study, when the doping ratio of MoS2 was 2:1, S-NiCoMo-2 exhibited the most outstanding catalytic performance for HER; when the doping ratio of MoS2 was 4:1, S-NiCoMo-4 provided the best catalytic performance for OER. To explore the efficient catalytic kinetics of S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4, we further analyzed their electrochemical surface area (ECSA) and charge transfer resistance (R ct). The electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) of all catalysts, including S-NiCoMo-4, S-NiCoMo-2, S-NiCoMo-0, and NiCo2S4 YSSs, was calculated from cyclic voltammetry curves to assess their ECSA as shown in Figs. S15 and S16. Typically, the C dl was considered to be directly proportional to the electrochemical surface area. As shown in Fig. 6(g), during the HER process, the C dl values for S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 were 49.2 and 45.1 mF cm–2, respectively, significantly higher than that of NiCo2S4 YSSs, which have a C dl value of 27.8 mF cm–2, and S-NiCoMo-0, with a C dl value of 21.9 mF cm–2. As shown in Fig. 6(h), during the OER process, the Cdl values for S-NiCoMo-4 and S-NiCoMo-2 were 31.5 and 27.1 mF cm–2, respectively, significantly higher than that of NiCo2S4 YSSs, which have a C dl value of 22.5 mF cm–2, and S-NiCoMo-0, with a C dl value of 13.2 mF cm–2. S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 exhibit the highest C dl value for HER and OER, respectively, reflecting their richly exposed catalytic active sites and significantly enhanced surface roughness, consistent with the superior advantages of the heterostructure. Notably, as illustrated in Fig. 6(i), based on the fitted equivalent circuit model extracted from the Nyquist plots, it can be observed that S-NiCoMo-2 exhibited the lowest charge transfer resistance, indicating its faster electron transfer capability. S-NiCoMo-2 (24.8 Ω) and S-NiCoMo-4 (38.7 Ω) demonstrated significantly lower charge transfer resistance than catalysts S-NiCoMo-0 (53.7 Ω) and NiCo2S4 YSSs (64.5 Ω) in alkaline electrolytes. This can be attributed to the introduction of MoS2 species, which enhanced the conductivity of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs, thereby facilitating electron transfer processes in both HER and OER. The substantial reduction in impedance indicates that rapid electron transfers significantly accelerated the kinetics of HER and OER for S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 catalysts. Based on these results, we speculate that the structures of S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 have more effective electrochemical active sites, which are beneficial to improving their HER and OER performance. Compared with the electrocatalytic performance of NiCo2S4 YSSs and S-NiCoMo-0, the doping of Mo element enabled NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs with a hollow structure and double shell electrochemical active sites to have lower overpotentials and Tafel slopes. This demonstrates that hollow nanospheres with a double-shell structure have unique advantages in water electrolysis. 3.3 Compatible AEM-LOM OER catalysis Based on whether proton and electron transfers occur simultaneously, typical electrochemical reactions can be classified into two types: concerted reactions and non-concerted reactions. To further investigate the cooperative catalytic mechanism involved in S-NiCoMo-4 and the origin of its OER activity, pH-dependent OER activity was evaluated, as shown in Figs. S13 (a)–(c). The OER activity of both S-NiCoMo-4 and S-NiCoMo-2 catalysts exhibit a strong pH dependence on the electrode, confirming that lattice oxygen is involved in the OER process [ 10 ]. Furthermore, identifying oxyanion species (such as peroxide O2 2– or superoxide O2 –) can provide additional evidence for the LOM pathway. The strong binding of tetraalkylammonium cations (TMA+) inhibits LOM [ 26,60 ]. When 1.0 mol L–1 tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) is added to the electrolyte as a chemical probe, the OER activity of S-NiCoMo-4 decreases significantly, as shown in Fig. 7(a) . The strong binding affinity between TMA+ and the oxyanion species generated by S-NiCoMo-4 during the OER process hinders the LOM pathway, explaining the reduced catalytic activity in this electrolyte. These results suggest that S-NiCoMo-4 and S-NiCoMo-2 induce non-concerted proton-electron transfer steps during the OER process. In situ Raman spectroscopy was employed to monitor phase transitions induced during the electrocatalytic process. In the Raman spectra shown in Fig. 7(b), the S-NiCoMo-4 curve displays a Raman peak at ~390 cm–1, corresponding to the Ag vibrational mode of CoS2; at 420 cm–1, corresponding to the A1g mode of MoS2; and at 181, 462, 509, and 665 cm–1, corresponding to the F2g, E2g, F2g, and A1g vibrational modes of NiCo2S4, respectively [ 61,62 ]. Under open-circuit potential (OCP), the NiCo2S4 structure undergoes reconstruction, and three new peaks appear at approximately 190, 480, and 685 cm–1, corresponding to the F1 2g, Eg, and A1g vibrational modes of Co3O4 [ 63 ]. This confirms the formation of Co spinel oxide on the surface, as the NiCo2S4 peaks vanish. A peak appears at 525 cm–1, corresponding to the A1g stretching vibration (ν(M–O)) mode in NiCoOOH* [ 64 ]. As the applied potential increases, the peak intensity of these Co3O4 species first increases and then decreases, accompanied by a new peak near 500 cm–1, which is attributed to the Eg mode of CoOOH* (vibration of O-Co-O bending along the a-b axis) [ 65 ]. At this stage, due to the anodic oxidation process, Co3O4 gradually converts into CoOOH*. More importantly, when the applied potential reaches 1.4 V, the Co3O4 signal is most prominent, indicating that the phase transition is complete. When the applied voltage exceeds 1.4 V, an A1g vibrational mode of CoO2 appears around 570 cm–1, attributed to proton extraction from CoOOH*, forming CoO2 [ 66 ]. As the applied potential increases to 1.8 V, the CoOOH* peak gradually weakens but does not disappear entirely, and an Eg vibrational mode of CoO2 emerges near 470 cm–1 [ 65 ]. CoOOH* does not fully convert to CoO2, possibly because CoS2 in S-NiCoMo-4 operates via an AEM mechanism, transforming into CoOOH* during the reaction without further conversion to CoO2. We hypothesize that Ni doping activates the pre-oxidation of Co within NiCo2S4 during the pre-OER redox process, leading to its transformation into Co3O4. As the potential increases, Co3O4 undergoes a phase transition to CoOOH*, which is then deeply oxidized to CoO2 through deprotonation. To determine whether Ni doping plays a critical role in triggering the LOM mechanism, in situ Raman characterization was performed on S-CoMo-4 obtained from an undoped precursor, as shown in Fig. 7(c). Under OCP, the Raman peaks of S-CoMo-4 are observed at ~390 cm–1 for the Ag vibrational mode of CoS2, at 420 cm–1 for the A1g mode of MoS2, and 457 and 530 cm–1 for the F2g and Ag modes of Co3S4, respectively [ 67 ]. The XRD spectrum of S-CoMo-4 is shown in Fig. S14. As the applied potential increases, the peak intensity of the Co3O4 species continuously diminishes, and a new peak appears around 500 cm–1, corresponding to the Eg mode of CoOOH*. At an applied potential of 1.3 V, another new peak emerges at ~600 cm–1, associated with the A1g mode of CoOOH* [ 66 ]. As the voltage increases from 1.3 to 1.7 V, signals for Co–O* [ 68 ], CoOOH* [ 69 ], and OOH* [ 70 ] can be observed, though with low intensity, while the intensity of OH* gradually increases. This indicates that in the AEM mechanism, the active intermediates O* and OOH* in the OER reaction can rapidly convert to the following products. In contrast, the OH* intermediate accumulates on the catalyst surface. In other words, compared to the electron transfer steps in the third (O* + OH– → OOH* + e–) and fourth (OOH* + OH– → O2 + H2O + e–) stages of the OER, the reaction rate of the second step (OH– + OH* → O* + H2O + e–) is the slowest. This results in a substantial accumulation of OH* intermediates awaiting the next reaction step. Thus, the second step is considered the rate-determining step, consistent with the experimentally observed and calculated rate-determining step based on maximum free energy change (Figs. 11(e) and (f) ). In situ Raman characterization of Co3S4@CoS2/MoS2 revealed no structural reconstruction, and CoO2 was not detected. This confirms that Ni doping is critical in triggering the LOM mechanism, as the S-CoMo-4 obtained from an undoped precursor follows the AEM mechanism. This is consistent with our hypothesis. To further verify the involvement of lattice oxygen in the OER process within S-NiCoMo-4, we employed in situ 18O isotope-labeled DEMS. We measured the product ratio of 34O2 (16O18O) to32O2 (16O16O) on 18O-labeled S-NiCoMo-4 and S-CoMo-4, as shown in Figs. 7(d) and (e) (methods provided in Supporting Information). DEMS measurements for both labeled and unlabeled S-NiCoMo-4 display m/z = 32 and m/z = 34 signals, indicating the generation of 32O2 and 34O2 gases. For labeled S-CoMo-4, the 34O2/32O2 ratio is 0.43%. Notably, the natural abundance of 18O in water is approximately 0.2%, which would produce at least 0.4% 34O2 in the O2 product. The 34O2 ratio for S-CoMo-4 after 18O exchange is close to this natural abundance value. This indicates that S-CoMo-4 strictly follows the AEM pathway during the OER process, with lattice oxygen not participating in the reaction, contributing to the catalyst's strong structural stability. In contrast, the 34O2/32O2 ratio for 18O-labeled S-NiCoMo-4 is 0.57%, significantly higher than the value of 0.43% for 18O-labeled S-CoMo-4 under the same testing conditions. This suggests that lattice oxygen is involved in the generation of 34O2. These results are consistent with those obtained from in situ Raman spectroscopy, demonstrating that Ni doping plays a crucial role in activating the LOM mechanism. Additionally, in situ Raman characterization and DEMS measurements for both S-NiCoMo-4 and Co3S4@CoS2/MoS2 confirm that S-NiCoMo-4 follows both the LOM and AEM reaction mechanisms during the OER process. In situ Raman spectroscopy analysis of HER was conducted immediately after OER testing of S-NiCoMo-4 at various potentials. As shown in Fig. 7(f), during the HER process, the unstable Co4+ in CoO2 is reduced to Co3O4 and ultimately to Co2+. The peaks of CoO2 around 470 and 570 cm–1 gradually disappear, while those of Co3O4 initially increase and then decrease [ 71 ]. Furthermore, as the voltage gradually decreases from –0.1 to –0.5 V, the OH* signal diminishes, while the Co–H* bond signal at 1100 cm–1 increases, indicating that the H* intermediate replaces the OH* intermediate on the active sites of Co. This further confirms that Co, rather than Mo, served as the catalytic active site for HER and OER in S-NiCoMo-4. Additionally, as the voltage decreases, the Co–H* signal initially increases and then stabilizes. At low voltages, HER is controlled by electron transfer; as the electrode surface potential becomes more negative, an increasing amount of H+ ions adsorbs onto the active sites to form H* [ 72 ]. As the voltage continues to decrease, HER becomes controlled by mass transfer. The reaction rate of adsorbed H* on the surface reaches equilibrium with the diffusion rate of H+ ions in the solution. In other words, the replenishment of H+ ions in the solution balances the adsorption of H*, resulting in a steady Co–H* signal intensity, at which point the mass transfer rate is maximized. Therefore, Ni doping achieves compatible regulation of two mechanisms for OER, enabling synergistic catalysis under the AEM and LOM pathways, as shown in Fig. 7(g). Meanwhile, the heterogeneous structure obtained through Mo doping enhances the adsorption of reaction intermediates for both HER and OER, optimizing performance in both processes. Furthermore, compared to some previously reported sulfide-based electrocatalysts, as shown in Tables S2 and S3, both the S-NiCoMo-2 and S-NiCoMo-4 catalysts exhibited outstanding catalytic activity and kinetic properties for HER and OER, respectively. As depicted in Fig. 8(a) , the 60 h chronoamperometry test results for both catalysts demonstrate their excellent catalytic stability in HER for S-NiCoMo-2 and in OER for S-NiCoMo-4. Based on the results above, we can attribute the exceptional dual-function catalytic activity of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs to their low charge transfer resistance, rapid mass transport capabilities, abundant electrochemical active sites, and stable morphology. Encouraged by these findings, we conducted overall water electrolysis experiments using S-NiCoMo-4 and S-NiCoMo-2 as the anode and cathode in a dual-electrode configuration electrolysis cell. As shown in Fig. 8(b), the polarization curve for water electrolysis illustrates the superior water electrolysis performance of the S-NiCoMo-4||S-NiCoMo-2 cell, which operated at a low cell voltage of 1.517 V and achieved a current density of 10 mA cm–2. This voltage was lower than that of the commercial catalysts IrO2||Pt/C, which requires 1.575 V. Additionally, by comparing the gas production measured using the drainage method in the experiment (Fig. 8(d) and Supporting Information Movie S1) with the theoretically calculated gas amounts, we determined the Faradaic efficiencies (FE) for the HER and OER processes during overall water splitting catalysis. The amount of gas produced in the experiment closely matches the theoretically calculated amount, with a molar ratio of approximately 2:1 for H2 to O2. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 8(c), the FE values during HER and OER are 97% and 95%, respectively. Table S4 demonstrates that it is comparable to or surpasses the performance of the most efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts reported to date. For example, it matched the 1.49 V voltage of the Cu-Ni3S2/Co3S4||Cu-Ni3S2/Co3S4 catalyst [ 73 ], exceeded the 1.54 V voltage of Mo-doped Ni2P catalysts featuring hollow nanostructures [ 74 ], and outperformed the 1.64 V voltage of the Ni/Mo2C-NCNFs catalysts [ 75 ], as well as the 1.6 V voltage of NCT-NiCo2S4 catalysts [ 76 ]. In addition, the chronoamperometry test conducted at a current density of 10 mA cm–2, as shown in Fig. 8(e), indicated that the S-NiCoMo-4|| S-NiCoMo-2 catalyst demonstrated outstanding long-term stability over 200 h, surpassing the durability of the Pt/C||RuO2 cell. Fig. 8(f) shows the bar chart in Table S4, which more clearly demonstrates the advantages of our electrocatalysts. The S-NiCoMo-4||S-NiCoMo-2 electrode pair was assembled into an AEM water-splitting device to evaluate its electrochemical performance and stability at high current densities as shown in Figs. 8(g) and (h), and Supporting Information Movie S2. Under commercial catalytic conditions (1 mol L–1 KOH), the S-NiCoMo-4||S-NiCoMo-2 provided a catalytic current of 500 mA cm–2 for 150 h with negligible degradation, as shown in Fig. 8(i). These results suggest that the synthesized NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHSs is a promising catalyst with the potential to replace precious metal catalysts, serving as a practical catalyst in large-scale industrial water electrolysis systems. Furthermore, as shown in Figs. S17 and S18, after three repeated experiments, the XRD, SEM, XPS, and electrochemical tests of NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 DSHS demonstrate that our catalyst exhibits excellent reproducibility. 3.4 DFT calculation It must be emphasized that a clear understanding of the electrochemical reaction mechanisms and surface charge distribution on catalysts is crucial for explaining catalytic activity, predicting and designing advanced electrocatalysts [ 77 ]. Therefore, we employed DFT calculations based on first principles to deepen our understanding of the Mott-Schottky effect, the changes in electron density at heterogeneous interfaces, and the potential reaction mechanisms of the CoS2/MoS2 catalytic system. We performed projected density of states (PDOS) calculations on isolated MoS2 (002) nanoparticles, the CoS2 (112) surface, and the CoS2/MoS2 heterostructure, and the specific results are shown in Fig. 9(a) . Generally, d-orbitals contribute more to the density of states near the Fermi level than p-orbitals, indicating their dominant role in the catalytic activity of the MoS2, CoS2, and CoS2/MoS2 systems. The PDOS results also reveal the semiconductor properties of the developed MoS2 nanoparticles with a sufficiently large band gap (1.43 eV) and the metallic nature of isolated CoS2 and the CoS2/MoS2 heterostructure. In the CoS2/MoS2 Mott-Schottky heterojunction, the coupling of the valence band and conduction band is enhanced. This phenomenon facilitates electron transfer across the band gap and promotes the kinetics of the HER and OER reactions [ 78 ]. The PDOS decomposition of the CoS2/MoS2 heterostructure reveals hybridization between MoS2 and CoS2 due to the newly formed Co–S bonds at the interface. To elucidate the natural electron transfer at the CoS2/MoS2 heterostructure interface, we determined the surface profile, as shown in the charge difference density in Fig. 9(b). In addition, we calculated the Bader charge transfer value to be 0.103 eV from CoS2 to MoS2. Analysis of Fig. 9(b) indicates that the electron density around Mo species is higher than that around Co species. The work functions of CoS2 and MoS2 are shown in Figs. S9(e) and (f). The vacuum and Fermi levels of CoS2 and MoS2 are 8.264, 4.796, 3.0198, and –0.378 eV, respectively. The calculated work functions of CoS2 and MoS2 are 5.174 and 5.244 eV, respectively. This confirms the transfer of electrons from the CoS2 portion to the higher work function MoS2, creating localized electrophilic and nucleophilic sites at the CoS2/MoS2 interface, consistent with XPS results [ 23 ]. More intriguingly, the difference in Fermi levels between CoS2 and MoS2 results in electron transfer across the heterojunction, modulating the electron densities around Co and Mo species (Figs. 9(c) and (d)). Free energy calculations were conducted for intermediates containing hydrogen and oxygen in the HER and OER over isolated MoS2, CoS2, and CoS2/MoS2 heterostructures to evaluate the adsorption capabilities of these key intermediates. The top and side views of the MoS2, CoS2, and CoS2/MoS2 crystal structures are shown in Fig. 10(a) . The diagrams in Figs. 10(b)–(d) illustrate the corresponding hydrogen adsorption sites for these systems. Co and S species are the adsorption sites for CoS2, Mo and S species for MoS2, and Mo, Co, and S species for CoS2/MoS2. The differences in Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) were calculated for CoS2, MoS2, and CoS2/MoS2 by subtracting the calculated Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption from the actual values for CoS2, MoS2, and CoS2/MoS2, respectively, as shown in Figs. 10(b)–(d). The calculated ΔG H* values for the Mo and S sites in MoS2 are –0.35 and 0.6 eV, respectively, which deviate significantly from the standard value of 0 eV, indicating only a moderate level of HER behaviour (Fig. 10(b)). For the CoS2 system, ΔG H* values were calculated for two different Co and S sites: Co sites with four adjacent S atoms (namely Co(4fld)), Co sites with five adjacent S atoms (namely Co(5fld)), S sites with two adjacent Co atoms (namely S(2fld)), and S sites with three adjacent Co atoms (namely S(3fld)). As shown in Fig. 10(c), the negative ΔG H* values for the Co(4fld) (–0.21 eV), S(2fld) (–0.61 eV), and S(3fld) (–0.15 eV) sites, indicating strong adsorption energies for the H intermediates at these sites. In comparison, the positive ΔG H* value for the Co(5fld) site (0.20 eV) suggests too weak a binding energy for the H intermediates, making adsorption and desorption of the H intermediates at these sites difficult, thus reducing the HER kinetic rate. This indicates that using CoS2 alone as an electrocatalyst for HER is not effective, which is consistent with the experimental results. It is worth noting that the optimal ΔG H* values for the Mo (–0.36 eV) and S (0.56 eV) sites belonging to the MoS2 component and the Co (–0.08 eV) and S (–0.15 eV) sites belonging to the CoS2 component in the CoS2/MoS2 heterostructure (Fig. 10(d)) confirm that the formation of the Mott-Schottky interface between MoS2 and CoS2 is conducive to the adsorption of H intermediates, thereby enhancing the kinetics of HER and the performance of the HER process. The adsorption energies of water molecules on the surfaces of MoS2, CoS2, and CoS2/MoS2, which directly affect the catalytic reaction kinetics, were calculated separately. Fig. 11(a) illustrates the theoretical models for the adsorption of H2O on the Mo top and edge sites of MoS2, the Co sites of CoS2, and the Co and Mo sites of the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction. As shown in Fig. 11(b), the adsorption energies of water molecules at the Mo top and edge sites of MoS2, the Co site of CoS2, and the Co and Mo sites of CoS2/MoS2 were found to be –0.13, –0.92, –0.49, –0.68, and –0.99 eV, respectively. The calculated adsorption energy of water molecules on the Co site of CoS2 was –0.49 eV. Furthermore, upon the integration of MoS2 and CoS2 components to form a Mott-Schottky heterojunction, the adsorption energies of water molecules on Mo (–0.99 eV) and Co (–0.68 eV) sites of CoS2/MoS2 are lower than those on individual MoS2 and CoS2, indicating that the adsorption of water molecules on the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction is thermodynamically more favorable than on MoS2 or CoS2 alone [ 79,80 ]. This heterostructure demonstrates a strong affinity for water molecules, enhancing catalytic performance under alkaline conditions. For the OER, we also calculated the differences in Gibbs free energy for O-containing intermediates (ΔG M*, M = OH, O, OOH) using DFT [ 81,82 ]. Generally, the fundamental OER process is governed by the four proton transfer mechanisms proposed by Norskow [ 78 ] and its efficiency mainly depends on the adsorption energies of OH*, O*, and OOH* on the catalyst surface. We have preliminarily calculated the ΔG M* of Co sites in the CoS2 system. Under alkaline OER conditions, the adsorption process of these intermediates on the Co sites of the CoS2 surface is shown in Fig. 11(c), and the corresponding free energy diagrams are shown in Fig. 11(e). The ΔG OH* value on the Co sites of CoS2 is very low, approximately 0.43 eV, significantly below the standard value of 1.23 eV, indicating a strong binding between Co and O* intermediates, which is detrimental to the overall OER kinetics. The calculated theoretical overpotential of OER on the Co sites of CoS2 is 0.93 eV, which is high, suggesting that the catalytic activity of CoS2 for OER is not ideal. Based on the maximum step size, the rate-limiting step for CoS2 is determined to be the formation of OOH*. On the other hand, the positive impact of modulating the heterojunction electronic structure on the intermediate adsorption barrier has not been confirmed yet after forming the CoS2/MoS2 Mott-Schottky heterojunction. Figs. 11(d) and (f) illustrates the adsorption process of the proposed o-related intermediates on the Co sites of CoS2/MoS2, along with the corresponding free energy diagrams under alkaline OER conditions. The ΔG OH* value (0.68 eV) of the Co site at the CoS2/MoS2 heterojunction is close to the ideal value (1.23 eV), indicating an optimal binding strength between Co and OH*. Therefore, the chemical coupling effect between MoS2 and CoS2 benefits OER kinetics, providing the optimal free energy for the adsorbed OER intermediates on CoS2/MoS2 and significantly reducing the overpotential to 0.52 eV. Additionally, the formation of O* at the Co site on the CoS2/MoS2 interface is considered the rate-determining step of the OER process. 4 Conclusions This study presents a novel approach by combining metal-organic framework MOF-derived core-shell structures with multi-element compositions to regulate the OER catalytic mechanism for NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 heterostructures. This design significantly enhances catalytic activity by optimizing core-shell stability and improving active species reconstruction and lattice oxygen activity through Ni and Mo doping. The catalyst demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance, with Mott-Schottky interactions effectively tuning the electronic structure of the heterojunction interface. DFT calculations show that the heterostructure optimizes the adsorption of HER and OER intermediates, enhancing water splitting efficiency. Additionally, the catalytic mechanism was confirmed by in situ Raman spectroscopy and 18O isotope labeling DEMS. Under the modulation of Ni and Mo, both AEM and LOM pathways are simultaneously optimized, providing new insights into the OER mechanism. The assembled anion exchange membrane water splitting device achieves a catalytic current of 500 mA cm–2 at 1.74 V under commercial operating conditions (1 mol L–1 KOH) for 150 h with negligible degradation. This study lays the foundation for designing high-performance electrocatalysts for water splitting, with potential applications in energy storage and environmental sciences. coredata.dc:description: Activating both metal and lattice oxygen sites for efficient oxygen evolution reactions (OER) is a critical challenge. This study pioneers a novel approach, employing cobalt-nickel glycerate solid spheres (CoNi-G SSs) as self-sacrificial templates to synthesize yolk-shell structured CoNi-G SSs@ZIF-67 nanospheres. The derived NiCo2S4@CoS2/MoS2 double-shelled hollow nanospheres integrate the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) and lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM), enabling synergistic dual catalytic pathways. Nickel modulation facilitates active species reconstruction in NiCo2S4, enhancing lattice oxygen activity and optimizing the LOM pathway. Characterization results indicate that anode activation triggered the redox processes of metal and lattice oxygen sites, involving the formation and re-filling of oxygen vacancies. Additionally, the CoS2/MoS2 heterostructure enhances the AEM pathway, as supported by density functional theory calculations, which demonstrate optimized adsorption of intermediates for both hydrogen evolution reaction and OER. The assembled anion exchange membrane water splitting device can deliver a catalytic current of 500 mA cm–2 at 1.74 V under commercial catalytic operating conditions (1 mol L–1 KOH) for 150 h, with negligible degradation. This work provides important insights into the understanding of OER mechanisms and the design of high-performance water-splitting electrocatalysts, while also opening new avenues for developing multifunctional materials with multi-shell structures.
